articles.author: Robin George Andrews
articles.description:
Recent flybys of the fiery world refute a leading theory of its inner structure — and reveal how little is understood about geologically active moons.            
The post What’s Going On Inside Io, Jupiter’s Volcanic Moon? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: What’s Going On Inside Io, Jupiter’s Volcanic Moon?

articles.author: Steve Nadis
articles.description:
Rose Yu has a plan for how to make AI better, faster and smarter — and it’s already yielding results.            
The post Improving Deep Learning With a Little Help From Physics first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Improving Deep Learning With a Little Help From Physics

articles.author: Carrie Arnold
articles.description:
Micro decisions can have macro consequences. A soft matter physicist reveals how interactions within simple cellular collectives can lead to emergent physical traits.            
The post How a Biofilm’s Strange Shape Emerges From Cellular Geometry first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How a Biofilm’s Strange Shape Emerges From Cellular Geometry

articles.author: Leila Sloman
articles.description:
According to mathematical legend, Peter Sarnak and Noga Alon made a bet about optimal graphs in the late 1980s. They’ve now both been proved wrong.            
The post New Proof Settles Decades-Old Bet About Connected Networks first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: New Proof Settles Decades-Old Bet About Connected Networks

articles.author: Steven Strogatz and Janna Levin
articles.description:
Quantum gravity could help physicists unite the currently incompatible worlds of quantum mechanics and gravity. In this episode, Monika Schleier-Smith discusses her pioneering experimental approach, using laser-cooled atoms to explore whether gravity could emerge from quantum entanglement.            
The post Can Quantum Gravity Be Created in the Lab? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Can Quantum Gravity Be Created in the Lab?
